summary: severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus (SARS-CoV) infection causes a progressive atypical pneumonia. most SARS patients recover, suggesting protective immune responses are operational. a strong host response is induced in the lungs of SARS-CoV–infected macaques. in the third phase, fatal cases of SARS progress to severe pneumonia and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), characterized by diffuse alveolar damage. pathological changes are caused by disproportional immune response, illustrated by elevated levels of inflammatory cytokines and chemokines. however, production of type I IFNs seems to be inhibited or delayed by SARS-CoV in vitro [14–18,20–22] cynomolgus macaques infected with SARS-CoV develop DAD similar to SARS patients, but clear most of the virus in the lungs by day 6. the ability to simultaneously examine virus replication and host response gene expression profiles in the lungs of these animals during the acute phase of SARS offers the opportunity to further unravel the pathogenesis of SARS. four mock-infected animals were included in the study to serve as a reference for host response without viral challenge. the level of infection in separate lung samples was evaluated using RT-PCR. no viral RNA could be detected in the samples from the mock-infected animals. RT-PCR was performed on all individual pulmonary samples from SARS-CoV–infected animals and mock-infected animals. the 12 samples from mock-infected animals were pooled and served as a reference sample. the number after PBS refers to the animal (i.e., PBS 1), while the number after the dash refers to the lung piece (i.e., PBS 1-1). there are two major roots to the hierarchical dendrogram. the larger root is composed of all the day 1 samples and the three day 4 samples with the highest virus levels. the smaller root is composed of the remaining day 4 samples with the lowest virus levels. thirty-eight genes are displayed with an absolute fold change > 2 and p 0.0001 in at least two animal samples. only one gene, HLA-DQA1, was down-regulated > 5. no up-regulated genes met these criteria in mock-infected animals. the heat map includes the 597 genes from the grey Venn diagram intersections. all 97 genes are listed in Figure S1. gene expression profiles are the results of comparing gene expression in lungs versus gene expression in lungs of mock-infected animals. the gene expression profile at day 1 shows a prominent innate host response to viral infection. top functional categories on day 1 are the immune response, the hematological system, and the immune and lymphatic system. at day 4, a smaller panel of unique differentially expressed genes were identified. expression of TFPI2 with these pro-coagulation genes might function as an inhibitory response to restrain the activation of the coagulation pathway during acute inflammation. a selection of genes involved in the immune response, cell cycle, or lung repair processes showed an absolute fold change > 5 and p 0.0001 in both day 1 animals. expression of diverse IFN- genes and expression of IFN- was up-regulated 10- to 20-fold in the day 1 samples. suppressor of cytokine signaling 1(SOCS1) is induced at the onset of infection. IFIT1 (ISG56/IFI56), often used to gauge IFN induction, was up-regulated an average of 13-fold. pathogenic and antiviral pathways are induced after SARS-CoV infection. a heat map was created showing all genes with expression changes > 2 and p 0.0001 in at least one of the samples with high SARS-CoV levels (A) and in at least one of the samples with low SARS-CoV levels (B) the heat map is segregated by functional annotations. the induction of IFN- was strongly correlated to the presence of virus (rspearman= 0.88, p 0.0001) for CXCL10 (IP-10), IL-6, and IL-8 the correlation is less evident.
